column10: notes

Residents are asked about garden management, opinions of wildlife. Researchers survey vegetation and vertebrate species in gardens. Water resouce in garden had more wildlife. Gardeners with more interest in wildlife had more wildlife. possible focal study and good background for NN cycle

Researchers surveyed marmoset populations in urban neighborhoods and other public spaces. Residents were interviewed about their interaction and observation of marmosets. Most people interact with the monkeys through food provision. Monkeys attracted to food in house. Domestic animals (dogs/cats) prey on or even play with the marmosets. possible focal?

Residents asked about sighting of stork, food provisioning, frequency of provisioning, motivation for feeding, and attachment to storks. 70% fed storks, 90% feed them year round, and 12% even named them. Unique provisioning study!

Study participants were given yard features of their choice to support wildlife (lizard, bird, bees, other habitat). Half of residents said they made more additions to yard after participating. Most people thought differently about their garden after participating. useful data
Use of nest boxes and supplementary food of hogs in residential yards. Could be cool focal?
People rescue more birds if they have better opinions of birds. Bird rescuers also plant more vegetation to attract birds.
bird traits -> resident opinion. Bird traits are related to people's opinions on birds, urban species have negative opinions.
All groups controlled moles to some extent, also provides opinions on whether those controls are 'humane'
Residents describe how they use their yards and what animals are annoying. Rodents, mosquitoes unwelcome. Squirrels, birds, deer, bunnies preferred.
citizen science, bats use peoples' swimming pools
types of mammals observed compared to anthropogenic resources and various disturbances

Residents bordering a botanical garden conservation area are asked about opinions of bandicoots and various controls/measures they take to attract them. This includes presence of dog/cat, rat poison, vegetation to attract bandicoots.
Residents use rodent bait stations to deter rats. Study tested the efficacy of elevated stations vs on the ground.
preference of deer browsing on spring-flowering plants in residential gardens and greenhouses. conditions the plant was grown in affects palatability.
residents were asked about barriers to obtaining/knowledge of various wildflowers. People dislike look of wildscaping and generally don't know where to obtain the plants. opinion of habitat
urban gardens and gardens with pesticide usage had less butterflies. garden quality positively associated with butterfly and bee abundance. uses pesticide
Yards bordering natural area.Most people have seen bandicoots in yard. 33% perceived as pest (digging), most people view them positively.
Most residents focused on topography of land rather than wildlife. Wildlife nuisance for some as they consumed their plants. Some people add features to see more birds or more bees.
Resident sightings of bandicoots in yard vs presence of cat or dog. sheltered garden with water resources had most bandicoot sightings. pets kill bandicoots
resident perception of birds impacts yard decisions, while actual change in biodiversity of yard doesn't necessarily cause residents to make changes in yards.
Larger gardens have more wildlife-encouraging activity. household density increases with garden feature density. 50% of households had garden features

Rural area, large houses. People have positive opinions and experiences with wildlife such as echidna. Removal of echidna from hole in yard. Remnant bush left for purpose of maintaining wildlife. People don't like when wildlife make mess (duck scat) or 'scary' species (snakes, dingoes). clear distinction between good and bad nature.

Residents reveal barriers to gardening for pollinators and try to find solutions. Major barriers are lack of knowledge and time. Also contains information about things people plant to attract pollinators (milkweed)
No resident interview, but bird feeders attracted mammals. keep?
Residents that hire landscapers. Most common support for wildlife is requesting to avoid invasive plants. Barriers, knowledge, maintenance for wildscaping. Focal study?
Resident opinions of snakes. Most people are afraid of snakes, whether people would kill them depends on gender and if snake is on private property.

column6: mowing regime, floral resources, pollinator counts
column10: Different mowing regimes deployed to study effect on bee community composition and floral resources. More flowers on lawn for mowing every two week, more bees for mowing every two weeks. experimental

People are asked about supplemental provisioning, nectar-providing flowering plants and occurrence of hummingbirds. People observed hummingbirds at a higher frequency in with an increase of both variables.
Attractants in yards for coyotes, i.e food, access to yard. Bird feeder most common attractant, followed by yard waste/compost. No resident opinion, only demographics.

People are asked about feelings of nature, size of garden and well-being in the context of nature connectedness. People that feel more connected to nature have larger gardens and more biodiversity. Nature connectedness positively affected well-being. habitat opinion only

Residents asked what kind of green infrastructure features they would like to see in their garden. Most common features they want are: pollinator gardens, biological pond, edible gardens and green roof.

Residents are asked about their opinions/knowledge of wildlife gardening and knowledge of HOA restrictions. Knowledgable people think pollinator gardening is easy. Most people believe HOAs restrict their ability to plant pollinator gardens or did not know, regardless of the actual policy.

Residents were interviewed for their knowledge on wildlife, and opinions of for the first interview. They were then provided ID information for wildlife followed by a 2nd interview to see change. People were able to ID species more accurately and specifically liked insects more after learning about them.

Gardens that contained wildlife-friendly structure were identified through a survey. Citizen scientists then surveyed the structures for wildlife and identified them. Pond feature was used by the most species. Bird baths has the most sightings (mostly birds). Researchers conclude usage of features was by a diversity of species, including those of conservation concern

School children (K-12) were asked about their sighting of coyotes, time of day, location. Most sightings were homes near forest. Residents in denser suburban areas had negative feelings toward coyotes and were less aware of them.
Residents were asked reason for planting native plants. Very few indicated that they plant native plants to support wildlife.
Residents were asked motivations for planting woody vs desert plants. Those who planted desert plants had more positive attitudes toward the desert and prioritized wildlife.
dead bees were found in bags of mulch which attracts bee larva. storage of bags could be detrimental to Megachile sp. Experimental

column6: insect sampling, bird/plant surveys, foraging behavior
column10: Preference of native vs non-native plants by chickadees. Preference depends on plant availability, but in areas with more natives, natives are preferred. no resident opinion

Experimental study that observes breeding pair access frequency of supplemental bird feeders in an experimental site (not actually residential and no resident opinion). No effect of supplemental feeding on breeding success.
infant crying experiment to see if foxes approach in backyard. exclude

CDA is an analysis of public recommendations excluding scholarly articles (i.e, forest preserve website).  No resident opinion, but government recommendations geared towards residents for management of flying foxes.
Residents are asked about native vegetation vs monoculture yards, social impact, etc. No opinions of wildlife
A farm manager said pollination is bad (only wildlife 'opinion'). growing food is more positively recieved. wildscapers in minority.
People liked blue, smaller songbirds the most. Less preference for orange, larger species. Not homeowners, undergrads
attitude to bison. 75% of people would vote for bison restoration, 45% actually in favor, fear influenced negative opinions. Too rural, remove?
